Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2010 05:11PM Denny123 wrote: Daisy, I am sorry to be so late to chime in.  I really should check in here more often.  By the time my bi-lat BC was found it had already spread to my liver.  But that wasn't confirmed until a year later when my CT scan showed a 9cm liver tumor and numerous 2cm tumors throughout. Before my mast, my surgeon did see a "spot" on my liver.  The first biopsy missed the spot and they got lung tissue.  The second biopsy sounded like yours-verrrry painful, and I had to keep holding my breath.  Horrible pain.  But that biopsy also missed the tumor. So I had my mast, chemo and rads, and the CT scan a year later showed the numerous tumors.  I then had a laporascopic liver biopsy and I was asleep, TG. Of course, I was very afraid since the liver is so important.  However..... I went on Gemzar and Herceptin and 9 months later I was in remission. I have remained in remission now for almost 6 years!!!!!! I am on Herceptin alone every 3 weeks and will have it for life, but that is fine with me.  Herceptin is keeping my liver in remission. I have talked and written to many ladies with liver mets and there are honestly so many chemos that work very well. I promise to check back in more often to see how you are doing and you will certainly be in my prayers. Denise

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2017 08:22PM Denny123 wrote: gramen-the reason for the antibiotics is because you had reconstruction. Did you have saline or silicone implants? If so, they are a foreign object just like a knee replacement. If you had a Tram flap or DIEP, you probably don't need antibiotics. I just had a filling today and my dentist said that I didn't need antibiotics, but I took 300mg of Cleosin anyway. When you have your teeth cleaned, is when the bacteria can enter your blood stream and cause an infection in your implants. So it depends on what kind of dental work you are having and if you had saline or silicone. Be sure to take a Probiotic, if you do take them.

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2018 05:40PM Denny123 wrote: I was on Kadcyla for almost 4 years with no hair loss. Watch for nose bleeds and if they start, try not to blow your nose.  Kadcyla thins the linings of the nasal passages so the capillaries are too close to the surface.  The best thing for bleeds is to put a bit of Afrin on a Q-tip and swab the inside of the nasal passages.  It constricts the passages and halts the bleeding.  Or you can spray Afrin into the nose, when needed.

For the bleeds, put some Afrin on a Q-Tip and swab the insides of your nostrils.  That usually stops it.  If not, spray the Afrin into the nostrils to constrict the blood vessels.

For the liver-In 2004 I had numerous mets to my liver from my BC. I had no pain at all. Lungs- Seldom pain in the beginning, only a cough that will get progressively worse through the years. Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2017 08:47PM Denny123 wrote: Fran-be careful with the nosebleeds. Kadcyla thins the nasal linings and thus the capillaries are too close to the surface. Try not to blow your nose....the last time I blew my nose forecefully was in April and I had to call an ambulance to take me to the ER and they couldn't stop the bleeding either. So I had to have my nose packed for a week-ugh. My ENT told me to use AYR saline spray and AYR gel to keep the nostrils moist. Also use a cool-mist vaporizer. And the best advice that I read on here was to put a few drops of Afrin on a Q-Tip and swab the inside of the bleeding nostril. If it won't stop bleeding, put Afrin on a bit of cotton, insert into the nose and hold it shut for 10 minutes. That will stop the bleeding. I did have the worst side cauterized a few years ago, but the whole inside can bleed. Denise

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2016 03:35PM Denny123 wrote: Yes, it seems to be a side effect of everything that I have been on. But I have been in the sun for over an hour and had no problem. But I seldom do burn. Lucky for me. Forgot to mention...about my nose bleeds. I finally figured it out....simply to NEVER blow my nose. In April I had to go to the ER since my nose would not stop bleeding. Kadcyla thins the lining of the nasal passages, thus making the capillaries too close to the skin surface. Since my nose runs a lot on Kadcyla, I had been blowing it lightly once in awhile. But just that was enough to cause irritation. The irritation caused bleeding, and then clotting. So then I was blowing my nose to get out the clots, which made everything worse. But since I have quit blowing my nose all together, I seldom even have the thin bloody discharge. I am praying that I don't get a cold!

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2018 01:45PM Denny123 wrote: DL3....  My onc had originally suggested Xeloda and Tykerb, or maybe he said OR instead of AND.  When I asked about it, he said it was a tough combo and they never give those 2 together anymore. Escorpian...Since you are already Stage 4, I doubt that the cancer would only go to that lymph node if it comes back.  And any recurrence would be seen with your scans.  When I just had one lymph node initially in my chest, I could have radiation on it.  But since it was so close to my esophagus, I didn't want to chance that.  So I decided to go with Kadcyla, and did go into remission.....for a few months. But it was a good decision to not radiate it since I got more cancerous nodes.....so obviously I needed chemo that would go through my whole system to protect it. So you could have it removed with surgery, radiation, or see if chemo would reduce it.  So, like DL3 says, wait to see what your onc says, and maybe he can discuss the situation with your radiation onc.

Posts.Title: thread on liver mets? Tracy1964 LuAnnH

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2010 02:23PM Denny123 wrote: BC metasis to the liver usualy presents with more than one tumor.  Radio Frequency Ablation can be used for a stubborn tumor 3cm or smaller.  That is, unless several smaller tumors are also starting to appear. However, if the BC has spread to the liver, systemic chemo is needed to get rid of cancer cells that have traveled throughout the body. A liver resection can get rid of that one tumor, but it doesn't stop other tumors from appearing.

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2017 11:58AM Denny123 wrote: Sorry Margarita-but I beat you! Well, yesterday was the beginning of my 16th year since being diagnosed with Stage 4 breast cancer.  I saw my onc today for the results of my PET scan. The cancerous node by my esophagus is about the same size, but more active.  But the tumors above my heart and the one at the entrance to my lungs have both gotten bigger, more active, and joined together to make one large node. So I am off Kadcyla now, after almost 4 years.  I have to take a month break and meanwhile will go through genomic testing for possible targeted therapy.  The testing searches for genomic alterations that can occur through time, and maybe there is a different kind of chemo that might stop the cancer. I will also go through consideration of a clinical trial Phase 2, of a new chemo, called Poziotinib. If I fail to qualify for either of the above options, I will have to go on a standard, but really hard combo of Xeloda and Tykerb, both of which are chemo pills. Radiation is not an option since I have already had rads to my left side. What a crappy year this has been.  Still recovering from a broken femur and shoulder from a fall in April.  I lost my 38 year old daughter in July.  And my other daughter is going to file for a divorce in a few days.  Now this.  Makes one wonder if stress really helps cancer to grow. I will still stop back in to visit everyone here.

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2018 09:59AM Denny123 wrote: DL3, I honestly was on the way over to comment on my new chemo when I saw the email notification of a post. I have been on Poziotinib for a week, and so far (maybe since I have been constipated for 4 years from the Kadcyla), no diarrhea.  I am taking stool softeners, actually. I had nausea for the first 3 days, but not the puking kind.   So far my side effects are mouth sores, a sore scalp, acne around my mouth, my nose bleeds are worse, loss of appetite, dry mouth, only a few finger cracks. But the best part is the weight loss!  I lost about 5 pounds in a week!  If I lose 17 more pounds I will be back to my pre-BC weight, which would be great. I eat a very small meal every 3 hours. I take 2 pills per day for 2 weeks, then I will have a week off.  Then 2 more weeks of pills, etc. My home-health psychology nurse daughter inquired about home health care, which will help, since they can access my chest port for the bloodwork that I need to get tomorrow.  I am in PA with frigid temps and snow. And I will have a number to call 24/7 with questions....like on day 2 when I had an allergic reaction in the late evening and my throat started to close up.  I took a Benadryl, which helped that, but wasn't sure if I could.  Talked to my nurse the next day and she said that Prednisone or Benadryl would work.  I prefer the OTC Benadryl. That hasn't happened again since that first day. Denise

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2008 12:57PM Denny123 wrote: Tracey, By the time my BC was dx'd it had alrady spread to my liver.  At its worst, my liver had a 9cm tumor, plus numerous 2cm tumors throughout.  I went on Gemzar with Herceptin(Phase 2 clinical trial at that time), and after 9 months or 14 treatments, my liver went into remission.  I have now been in remission for over 3 1/2 years, and have been on Herceptin for over 4 years total.  I will continue on Herceptin for life. My heart ejection fraction actually went up with my last echo-between 55-60. Gemzar was sooo easy for me-just a little nausea the evening of treatment, and some hair thinning.  I did have a very fine light rash, nothing major(made me look healthy and rosy!).  I also drank 4 ounces of RED grape juice daily as it is supposed to help with the platelets, and my platelets were fine the whole time.  (Can't hurt-might help category)! Please feel free to ask any other questions.  If my liver mets return, I will definitely go back on Gemzar. Denise

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2010 10:52PM Denny123 wrote: Hi, By the time my bi-lat BC was dx'd, it had also already spread to my liver.  At its worst, I had a 9cm tumor in my liver and numerous 2cm tumors throughout.   My onc. prescribed a biopsy to make sure that it was bc mets, so he could be sure what kind of chemos to give me.  If it is another primary, like colon CA, etc, different chemos are necessary.  So I absolutely agree with the biopsy.  If it is not BC mets to the liver, the BC chemos will NOT work on your tumors. I had Gemzar with Herceptin and 9 months later my liver went into remission, and I am still in remission, 5 1/2+ years later. I am on Herceptin for life, and have no SE's at all with it. With all of my tumors, I had no pain, so I agree that the pains could be caused by something else.  When I did start on Gemzar, I did have some liver pains and my onc said that that meant that the Gemzar was working.  And he was right.  After that, the pains were much easier to tolerate-knowing that the chemo was kicking butt. You will be in my prayers. Denise

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2011 12:07AM Denny123 wrote: Fatima, I was Stage 4 from the get-go also, with liver mets-8 years ago.  At its worst, my liver had a 9cm tumor and numerous 2cm tumors throughout. I had Gemzar with Herceptin and my liver went into remission  9 months later.  I have continued on Herceptin alone and have beenin remission now for 6 1/2 years. I think a biopsy is indicated to make sure that the liver mets are from the breast cancer.  They may be from another primary CA and different chemos wold be required. Otherwise, if the mets are from BC, there are many other chemos that can do a great job. Best of luck to you! Denise

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2010 11:15PM Denny123 wrote: Hi Marina, My biggest liver met was 9cm and I had numerous 2cm mets through out my liver.  I had Gemzar and Herceptin and in 9 months my liver went into remission.  I have now been in remission for 5 1/2+ years and have remained on Herceptin only which is truly keeping me in remission. So Her2Neu+ is a good thing.  My liver mets grew in spite of my original tx of Taxotere, so my onc. chose not to use the Taxanes. But Taxol can be very effective.  If not, there are a lot of other chemos that will kick your liver mets to the curb. Good luck! Denise
